div.p: This sub-element is found in BIOGRAPHY CULTURALFORMATION . Within those tags, it might or might not also be within RACEANDETHNICITY, captures information about a person's perceived or lived racial identity. See RACEANDETHNICITY for a detailed description of the complexities of this element. It encloses usually a single word, occasionally more, and has optional attributes of FOREBEAR, SELFDEFINED and REG (allowing you to standardize the raceColour if this is desirable but not feasible in your prose). We have tried to counter the effect of white as default by sentences like She was presumably white or by inserting an empty RACECOLOUR tag with REG value white.

div.codeblock: Both of Aguilar's parents were presumably <RACECOLOUR FOREBEAR="parents">white</RACECOLOUR> and of <NATIONALHERITAGE>Spanish</NATIONALHERITAGE> <ETHNICITY FOREBEAR="parents">Jewish</ETHNICITY> descent.
MP is a <RACECOLOUR>black</RACECOLOUR> woman writer originally from the Caribbean.

div.p: Although we do not want to insist on naming the presumed whiteness of British women writers in every case where we presume whiteness, it is sometimes very effective to do so. We especially want to do this in cases where there is some question about the writer's whiteness (e.g. Elizabeth Barrett Browning). Whiteness should also be named in the cases of colonial women travellers and everyone else from after World War II when a sizeable resident non-white population re-established itself in Britain. To do this, we ask that you open an empty RACECOLOUR element (if not already used in the prose) and regularize the attribute to white.
